Yes. Consider the descriptions for each of the major philosophers listed at Rationalism, all of whom were religious. The modern opposition between religion and "being rational" is an oversimplified social conflict arising from the conservative backlash of Protestantism, as it has developed, mostly in the United States, after beliefs about Biblical accounts being literally and historically true began to be controverted by discoveries made in the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries as fields of the natural and other sciences--paleontology, geology, biology--that painted a very different picture about things about the world and the planet that had been long assumed to be true based on the Bible. That backlash grew out of Sola scriptura, a doctrine common to all Protestant denominations that scripture is one of the only requirements for a Christian to merit salvation, i.e. all you need do is read the Bible.  Historically, this likely arose as a move to reject all the "expanded universe" canonical writings made by the Catholic clergy in order to remove justification for their positions of clerical and divine authority.  The masses shouldn't be excluded for not paying enough gold to priests, who were all corrupt at the time anyway. Effectively, this seems to have resulted in later Protestants commonly reasoning that, if it's not in the Bible, and it says something contradicting the Bible, the Bible is right and screw that other crap. Yet, the silliness of such reasoning seems to have been lost on those literalist Protestants, especially if you:  look at that the dates when those rationalist Christian thinkers lived, consider how many of them continued to be both religious while rejecting literal interpretation of the Bible to the exclusion of anything else,and consider that all of them long pre-dated the birth of these Science vs. the Bible conflicts.Your perception that atheists would think that way is incorrect, and if your atheist friends do think that way, they have likely fallen under the whole "Science (Rationality) is always opposed to Religion, and vice versa" false conflict and are likewise incorrect. "Rationalism" really just refers in philosophy to the concept that knowledge can be acquired by using reason (and generally or only using reason).  Most of these religious (and very Christian, even Protestant) rationalists lived during the periods of the Renaissance and Enlightenment.  They argued and believed that reason was a gift given by God to all men, that it was intended to be used for such purpose, and that it was rather nonsensical that God would thus reserve divinity in defiance of human reason, effectively hiding it behind a shroud of mysticism.  Even from an atheist standpoint, if God actually exists, it wouldn't make sense that God would grant humans the faculty of reason if you are simultaneously supposed to distrust it so regularly or even at all. Reasoning by rationalist Christian thinkers in argument for religion and the existence of the Christian god generally proceeded by beginning with concepts that were ideally perfect, like mathematics, and using mathematical deduction and induction to do things like prove the existence of God must be also be true, i.e. because proofs in math are also true.  Even as far back as the time of the Catholic philosopher, St. Thomas Aquinas, who I believe is sufficiently "rational" in his reasoning and argumentation, you see rationalist reasoning making cases for the Christian god being the perfectly benevolent and omniscient|omnipotent being he is depicted as today. In case you're wondering why an atheist wouldn't buy such reasoning, that's a much longer group of different arguments, most of which probably occur to atheists at different times. Firstly, any conclusions arrived at purely via reason must always rely on axioms, that is base assumptions one must accept as true (perhaps as self-evidently true).  What this means is you aren't actually producing new knowledge, you're starting with things you already know, perhaps because they are obvious, and using correct and consistent reasoning to arrive at a necessary implication of those things you started with, a conclusion that may not in fact have been obvious at all.  Mathematical proofs and theorems are of this sort.  So rationalism serves to root out confusion in ones thinking. The other implication of this is that two people can both use logically correct reasoning to arrive at contradictory conclusions if they each begin with different assumptions.  As you can imagine, we see this a lot between atheists and theists.  You even see this between different theists.  This is probably about as desirable an outcome as one could hope to have between an atheist and a theist bent on discussing such matters: to be able to find each other's reasoning consistent and not-self-contradictory! Secondly, as other respondents have stated, rationalism alone is only a useful tool for "gaining" knowledge in certain subjects, such as mathematics.  Beyond a certain point, correct reasoning isn't capable of leading you to acquire new knowledge.  For that, you need observation.  More specifically, you need the ability to compare new observations against past observations.  You need the ability to make them repeatedly and independently of other observers.  This is Empiricism. This allows one to account for the possibility of false or erroneous testimony.  Even like in the Bible, false testimony can be a sticky problem.  By contrast, the Bible and much of Christianity relies fundamentally on testimony as the basic assumption by which one gains knowledge (you see remnants of this all over the linguistic "archaeological" record of Christianity's history--consider how often the words "testify!" and "testimonial" are used--consider that both books of the Bible are referred to as "testaments"--someone somewhere who is expected to be trustworthy has attested that such and such a thing they witnessed was true), and hence the severity of its prohibition against false testimony. Now, to be clear, it's philosophically okay to make an epistemological assumption that testimony is a perfectly acceptable basis by which one attains knowledge that something is true.  It is the case that false testimony is the enemy of ascertaining truth and knowledge.  Just be aware that any sensible critic of yours would immediately raise the objection of how patently unreliable testimony itself is, even in our modern age given the incentives and lack of consequences or enforcement against falsification of evidence or accounts, to say nothing of questionably "historical" events claimed to have occurred thousands of years ago by parties with stakes in the outcome. Going back, atheists are often so particularly fond of science because the scientific method systematically relies on both rationalism and empiricism in order to attain knowledge about the world everyone is forced to share.  The conclusions produced by it, while not being all-encompassing, lead to incrementally greater knowledge than previously had, about the physical world and universe we inhabit and all experience, and to the best of our collective ability, at least insofar as is logistically practical to do so, and at least insofar as when scientific method is practiced correctly. Scientific knowledge is a "belief" in the technical sense of the word as used in philosophy, but it's not a (just a) "belief" in the colloquial sense.  Science is about reality.  Scientists, religious or non-religious, don't "believe" something just because they choose to.  Scientists believe something because they should be unable to conclude otherwise after falsifying other explanations and validating against errors in data of observations, and following experiments that anyone should be capable of repeating given the same equipment and physical scenarios and following the same instructions in earnest. But yes, rationalism, by itself, isn't intrinsically opposed to religion.  In fact, much Christian doctrine has evolved to establish baseline axioms by which one can completely conclude all of Christianity's claims.  The other key epistemological axiom in Christian doctrine is that knowledge can be also be attained by revelation, i.e. that God, or any supernatural being (one that communicates from beyond any natural means of detection or interaction, outside the universe, for instance), speaks directly to a person, who is a believer.  An example of revelation would be God talking only to the Pope and his immediate subordinates in Catholicism.  Or God, or Jesus, speaking directly to Protestant worshipers.  Or Allah speaking directly to Muhammad.  Or Cthulhu speaking directly to his cultists.  Or the Flying Spaghetti Monster speaking directly to that 14-year old. Obviously, revelation carries its own host of problems, namely how in the hell one distinguishes a true prophet or revelation from just any other crackpot hearing voices in their head and making wild claims.  (I believe this is addressed in some fashion in the Bible and Qur'an, but I suspect no atheist who's considered the argument finds it at all sufficient.)  Of course, I suppose that's what the value of true testimony is for.

Let’s go through three questions in turn, starting with the previous, superior formulation: Can a person be both rational and religious? As a preliminary point, just to be thorough about it, a homicide detective can be entirely rational in his approach and yet identify Polanski as the perpetrator when in fact Harper did the deed. The point, of course, is that rationality does not rule out error. To answer this first question, then, yes, in principle a person can take the rational approach, get caught up in error, and remain religious. But that is far more likely if he (let’s say) is ignorant and hence proceeds from false premises, or bad at logic and hence draws invalid inferences (“The flowers are so pretty, so God must exist!”). But perhaps you have the following in mind: Can a person pursue the rational approach to the end and yet remain religious? It depends on what you mean by “to the end,” and on the religion in question. If you mean to the point at which the truth of the matter is firmly established, then of course he can pursue the rational approach to the end and yet remain religious only if his religion is true—that is, only if the core tenets represent the truth. But this means the objective truth, for there is no other variety. If such-and-such is not true objectively then it does not represent reality, and if it does not represent reality, then it is not true at all. Note that if he resorts to faith in the religious sense (“I’m going to forget all the controversy and just believe it!”) then he has abandoned the rational approach, which violates the conditions. To resort to faith is not to pursue the rational approach. On the contrary, it is to refuse to pursue it. In my opinion, in the final analysis, a religion that essentially posits the supernatural (“A supreme supernatural being created the natural physical world,” for example) simply fails to make a jot of sense. It is just a load of gibberish. But if that is so, then the rational approach eventually washes up at that conclusion, in which case it is necessary to abandon the religion, or else rationality. In the end, however, I think that the question you have in mind is best put in terms of society as opposed to the individual, as follows, for example: In the long run, across many generations into the future, will rationality leave room for religion? I do not think so. Religion has been on the way out for centuries, and it will continue on its way out, barring a global catastrophe that leaves the few miserable survivors desperate and in need of reassurance. That is because it does not represent reality, but merely virtual reality, or in other words, imagination.
